questions.text: A 59-year-old male complains of visual loss and visual field defects. On the exam, IOP is 20 mm Hg. The exam findings are shown in the images below. Which of these statements is correct about this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Overall CCT in these patients is higher than in POAG

options.label: B
options.text: Patients tend to be younger than those with POAG

options.label: C
options.text: Abnormal Vascular regulation has been found more commonly in these patients than POAG

options.label: D
options.text: Ocular perfusion pressure may be relatively higher than in POAG.

questions.correct_answer: C. Abnormal Vascular regulation has been found more commonly in these patients than POAG
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Abnormal Vascular regulation has been found more commonly in these patients than POAG The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of normal tension glaucoma . The first image shows glaucomatous damage in normal-tension glaucoma; while the second image shows presence of splinter hemorrhage . Splinter haemorrhage on the disc margin is more frequent than in POAG and is associated with a greater likelihood of progression. These are often missed if the disc is not photographed or is examined without magnification.

Highyeild:

Abnormal vasoregulation , particularly migraine and Raynaud phenomenona , has been found more commonly in NTG than POAG .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. With the introduction of widespread CCT assessment , NTG in some patients can be explained by very low CCT. Overall CCT in patients with NTG is lower than in POAG. Option: B. Patients tend to be older than those with POAG, though this may be due to delayed diagnosis. Option: D. Ocular perfusion pressure may be relatively lower than in POAG. The translaminar pressure gradient may on average be larger than in POAG.

questions.text: Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is an optic neuropathy of adult onset. Which of these statements is true for this disease process?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a predilection for the female gender.

options.label: B
options.text: Characteristic visual field loss, that occurs as damage progresses, is a key modifiable risk factor.

options.label: C
options.text: Asymmetry of IOP of 3-4 mmHg is considered significant.

options.label: D
options.text: Myopia is associated with an increased incidence of POAG

questions.correct_answer: D. Myopia is associated with an increased incidence of POAG
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Myopia is associated with an increased incidence of POAG Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a chronic, progressive optic neuropathy of adult onset. Myopia is associated with an increased incidence of POAG, and myopic eyes may be more susceptible to glaucomatous damage.

Highyeild:

According to various studies, it is suspected that myopic discs are more susceptible to glaucomatous damage at a lower IOP than emmetropic discs.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: It affects both genders equally. Option: IOP is a key modifiable risk factor. Characteristic visual field loss may occur as damage progresses, but it is a sequela rather than a risk factor. Option: The higher the IOP, the greater the likelihood of glaucoma . n asymmetry of IOP of 4 mmHg or more is also significant.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male was referred to the ophthalmology department due to the following exam findings by his family physician: His visual acuity is normal. On exam, a relative afferent pupillary defect was excluded. IOP was recorded to be significantly higher than normal. Which of the following statements is not true about this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Disc haemorrhages are common in such cases.

options.label: B
options.text: Double angulation of a blood vessel frequently occurs in these cases.

options.label: C
options.text: The laminar dot sign occurs in the initial stages of this disease.

options.label: D
options.text: An optic disc haemorrhage is a risk factor for the development and progression

questions.correct_answer: C. The laminar dot sign occurs in the initial stages of this disease.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The laminar dot sign occurs in the initial stages of this disease. The given case history and findings point towards the presence of glaucomatous changes in the patient. The image shows concentric enlargement with deep uniform enlargement of the optic cup. The laminar dot sign occurs in advancing glaucoma.

Highyeild:

Grey dot-like fenestrations in the lamina cribrosa become exposed as the NRR recedes. The fenestrations sometimes appear linear, and this itself may be a sign of advanced damage, indicating distortion of the lamina. The dots may be seen with normal eyes.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Disc haemorrhage often extends from the NRR onto the retina, most commonly inferotemporally . When screening for glaucoma, approximately three out of four people with a disc haemorrhage will not have glaucoma. Their presence is a risk factor for the development and progression of glaucoma. Option: B. Bayoneting is characterized by double angulation of a blood vessel. With NRR loss, a vessel entering the disk from the retina may angle sharply backwards into the disc and then turn towards its original direction to run across the lamina cribrosa. Option: D. An optic disc haemorrhage is a risk factor for the development and progression of glaucoma and can be missed unless magnification is used to examine the disc.

questions.text: A 59-year-old female presents with frequent changes in presbyopic correction and frequent headaches. Gonioscopy reveals a normal open angle. The C/D ratio is 0.5 in the right eye and 0.7 in the left. Visual acuity is normal. What is the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Primary angle closure glaucoma

options.label: B
options.text: Ocular hypertension

options.label: C
options.text: Primary open angle glaucoma

options.label: D
options.text: Senile changes

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primary open angle glaucoma The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of primary open angle glaucoma ( POAG ). POAG is generally asymptomatic, and SS patients may have nonspecific complaints such as: Headache Frequent changes in presbyopic correction Noticing a ‘blind spot’ or scotoma, especially if present in the inferior field difficulty in dark adaptation .

Highyeild:

To make a diagnosis of POAG , the presence of a normal, open angle should be confirmed by gonioscopy. The presence of optic nerve head changes suggestive of glaucomatous damage, including: A cup-to-disc ratio of more than 0.5

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Primary angle - closure disease includes a spectrum of conditions in which the peripheral iris moves forward to block the openings of the trabecular meshwork at an occludable angle, causing a rise in intraocular pressure. Females are more commonly affected by acute PACG, but in the asymptomatic or ‘creeping’ chronic variety, males and females are equally affected. Option: B. Some individuals, physiologically, have an intraocular pressure of more than 21 mm Hg, without any optic nerve head or field abnormalities and are called ocular hypertensives. Option: D. Senile changes may lead to the presence of presbyopic process but it does not explain the rest of the history and exam findings.

Extraedge:

An asymmetry between the cup-to-disc ratio of two eyes of more than 0.2. Narrowing, notching, or pallor of the neuroretinal rim

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with significant visual defects and a loss of visual field. On examination, the C/D ratio is 0.6 in both eyes. On gonioscopy, the angle is normal and open. The patient reports that he has changed his glasses three times in the last six months. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this case?

options.label: A
options.text: The frequent changes in glasses are due to constant pressure on the ciliary muscle.

options.label: B
options.text: The prevalence of this disease is higher in patients suffering from Graves’ ophthalmic disease than in the normal population.

options.label: C
options.text: In the initial stages, the IOP may not be raised permanently, but there is an exaggeration of the normal diurnal variation.

options.label: D
options.text: IOP is the most common and only risk factor for the development of these symptoms.

questions.correct_answer: D. IOP is the most common and only risk factor for the development of these symptoms.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IOP is the most common and only risk factor for the development of these symptoms. The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of primary open angle glaucoma (POAG). POAG is generally asymptomatic, and patients may have nonspecific complaints such as: Headache Frequent changes in presbyopic correction Noticing a ‘blind spot’ or scotoma, especially if present in the inferior field Difficulty in dark adaptation To make a diagnosis of POAG, the presence of a normal, open angle should be confirmed by gonioscopy. IOP is the most common risk factor, but it is not the only risk factor for the development of glaucoma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Difficulty in reading and close work, often persistently increasing, is experienced by most patients. This occurs due to increasing accommodative failure as a result of constant pressure on the ciliary muscle and its nerve supply. Therefore, patients usually complain of frequent changes in presbyopic glasses. Option: B. The prevalence of POAG is higher in patients suffering from Graves’ ophthalmic disease than in the normal population. Option: C. In the initial stages, the IOP may not be raised permanently, but there is an exaggeration of the normal diurnal variation. Therefore, repeated observations of IOP (every 3–4 hours), for 24 hours are required during this stage (diurnal variation test) . In most patients, IOP falls during the evening, contrary to what happens in angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: Which of the following options is a pathologic visual field defect occurring during glaucomatous optic neuropathy secondary to primary open angle glaucoma. Select the correct answer from the given below code:

options.label: B
options.text: 1, 2 and 4 only

options.label: C
options.text: 1, 2 and 3 only

options.label: D
options.text: 1,3 and 4 only

questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3 and 4 Glaucomatous field defects should always be interpreted in conjunction with clinical features (IOP and optic disc changes).

Random:

Explanation for all options: - Option: A. Image shows Bjerrum’s scotoma , which is a characteristic field defect caused by glaucomatous optic neuropathy secondary to primary open angle glaucoma. It is also considered to be an early glaucomatous change, but it is very nonspecific and thus of limited diagnostic value. Option: B. Image shows a superior paracentral scotoma , which is a characteristic field defect caused by glaucomatous optic neuropathy secondary to primary open angle glaucoma. It is the earliest clinically significant field defect. Option: C. .The image shows a double arcuate scotoma and Roenne’s central nasal step, which are characteristic field defects caused by glaucomatous optic neuropathy secondary to primary open angle glaucoma. Roenne’s central nasal step is created when the two arcuate scotomas run in different arcs and meet to form a sharp right-angled defect at the horizontal meridian. Option: D. The image shows Seidel’s scotoma , which is a characteristic field defect caused by glaucomatous optic neuropathy secondary to primary open angle glaucoma. With the passage of time, paracentral scotoma joins the blind spot to form a sickle-shaped scotoma known as Seidel’s scotoma.

questions.text: 55-years-old patient comes to OPD with headache, difficulty in reading, delayed dark adaptation, and significant loss of vision. On examination, intraocular pressure was found to be 40mmHg.What is the pupillary abnormality observed in this patient of primary open angle glaucoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Amaurotic Light Reflex

options.label: B
options.text: Wernicke's hemianopic pupil

options.label: C
options.text: Marcus Gunn pupil

options.label: D
options.text: Adie's tonic pupil

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Marcus Gunn pupil Primary open-angle glaucoma commonly causes bilateral and asymmetric optic nerve damage. Impaired pupillary constriction due to a defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye, causes a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test. The flashlight is swung to and fro, and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils remain constricted. In the presence of RAPD, the affected pupil dilates when moving the flashlight from the normal eye to the abnormal eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil. It is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease .

Highyeild:

Causes of RAPD : Severe retinal disease (e.g., central retinal artery occlusion, extensive retinal detachment) Maculopathy (macular degeneration) Optic nerve lesions (e.g., optic neuritis, retrobulbar neuritis in multiple sclerosis, anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, glaucoma) Optic tract lesions (e.g., infarction.)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Amaurotic light reflex Option: B . Wernickes hemianopic pupil Option: D . Adies tonic pupil
